++ 10 September
[[/=]]

----

The debriefing ended around four in the morning, and they all wandered back to their dorms to get some sleep. Harry expected to rest only fitfully, but ended up waking around two in the afternoon. A quick check of his tablet revealed that he was expected back at Ngo's office by three to finish presenting the narrative, then start drilling down into the details.

A quick check of his laundry hamper revealed that someone, probably Sokolsky, had come in during the night to steal the clothes he'd been wearing as O5-2. Maybe Lillian had let him in.

He took a shower, selected something that looked comfortable enough -- all of his clothes were unfamiliar now, even the ones he'd had for years -- and headed back to resume the ordeal.

Lillian was still wearing her dazzle coat, the same one she'd donned to wait out the initial timeline shift. Apparently there wasn't much difference in fashion sense between her two versions. McInnis dressed like he always did; Nascimbeni and Del had switched back to their jumpsuits, though neither looked precisely comfortable in them. Nascimbeni's eyes were buried under thick purple bags, and Harry suddenly wondered whether he'd been drugged for the first half of the debriefing. He'd seemed preternaturally calm for someone who'd just lost a year's worth of reunion with his son, and now looked like he'd just come back from an hour-long crying fest.

He felt a pang of guilt over noticing these things. A good night's sleep and a quick shower, and he'd only thought about his... vanished wife every few minutes instead of non-stop. It felt like a betrayal. It felt //unfaithful.//

//Oh,// he thought. //I don't want to do any of this.//

Udo was wearing a corduroy sweater, navy blue, a little like the one she'd borrowed from Corbin. He wondered how much she was hurting right now, and how much of it was his fault.

[[=]]
@@ @@
[[image http://scp-wiki.wdfiles.com/local--files/the-b-b-decommission/Asterisk43.png]]
@@ @@
[[/=]]

McInnis hadn't lost a lover. He hadn't, in point of fact, ever had one. He hadn't lost his family  at least, not because of the timeline reset. So far as the O5 Council would be concerned when he made his carefully-curated report, the Director of Site-43 hadn't lost anything at all.

This was not, of course, remotely true.

But with the ghost of Vivian Scout hovering over him as he sat at his desk, organizing his thoughts for the next debriefing session, he knew he had to gain something from the experience. It had to have meaning. It had to make him better at what he did, because what he did //mattered.//

So he opened his most private of files, the ones he kept on paper under lock and key, and began to make notes. Not on the topic of friendship, at least not directly, or romance, or war, or violent death. On a topic the ever-present spectre would understand, and appreciate.

The topic of leadership.

He had already been instructed not to do this. To make no permanent record of anything he had experienced that was not first channeled through the person of his chosen psychologist. That was the only thing the Council, with their infinite wisdom and limited time to waste on him today, despite the mammoth implications of what had happened, had chosen to tell him so far. Their only order.

He wasn't sure what it said about him yet, the decision to utterly ignore them for the first time in his long career.

But as he'd once been instructed by the only authority he really, truly trusted, he intended to take the next available moment to consider it.

[[=]]
@@ @@
[[image http://scp-wiki.wdfiles.com/local--files/the-b-b-decommission/Asterisk43.png]]
@@ @@
[[/=]]


Another three hours of dredging up bad memories took the fight out of all of them. Ngo was agog the entire time. Del and Lillian delighted in a few of the highlights, apparently able to distance themselves from the events now that their existence was purely academic, but it didn't work that way for Harry. He'd lived that life. In spite of all the pain and loss, he'd found peace and fulfillment in it. This felt less like a reminiscence than an autopsy and rape kit procedure on a loved one.

[[div class="Ngo"]]
**Dr. McInnis:** We still came //this close// to failing, though.

**Chief Ibanez:** My fault. Should've seen it coming.

**Dr. Wettle:** I //told you// I could hear tapping in the bedrock.

**Chief Ibanez:** You were saying that for months. You couldn't possibly have heard it.

**Dr. Ngo:** Heard what?

**Chief Ibanez:** Markey. He'd been clawing his way back out of Ambrogi's hole since November of last year. Probably not an easy thing, when solid rock turns to dust under your fingertips.

**Dr. Okorie:** He broke through two days before the breach recurred, and started cutting researchers in half.

**Chief Ibanez:** Yeah. Thank god for the Red Right Hand and their Bremmel-blasters.  But I've gotta say... it's really good to see you again, Nhung. You didn't deserve what happened.

**Dr. Ngo:** Wait, what?

**Dr. Blank:** She's just fucking with you.

**Chief Ibanez:** Yeah, yeah. But hey, I did get to see what Trevor Bremmel's bowels look like on the inside, before they splattered Markey.

<Silence on recording.>

**Chief Ibanez:** Looked like he'd had chili for dinner.
[[/div]]

[[=]]
@@ @@
[[image http://scp-wiki.wdfiles.com/local--files/the-b-b-decommission/Asterisk43.png]]
@@ @@
[[/=]]

That was really the last straw for him. He found himself slamming open the door yet again, and wondered //is this what post-traumatic stress feels like?//

...

//...is __what__ like post-traumatic stress feels like?//

Udo was standing in the hall again. This time he'd seen her slip out; it had been during Del's enthusiastic description of kicking Janet Gwilherm's face in. This time, she was the one who waved. "Hey."

"Hey." He had the strangest feeling he was supposed to be angry with her. Did that make any sense?

She looked similarly at a loss. "So..."

"Yeah," he agreed. "Yeah..."

"I don't remember it." He'd never seen her amber eyes so wide.

He sat down on his haunches, and breathed deeply. "Me either. What the fuck?"

She hunched down with him. "At all."

"Me either." He shook his head. He glanced at his watch.

6:29.

"For," he said, "fuck's, sake."

The memories were gone. All of them. Every single one. Not the memory of passing the memories on to Ngo; he could still picture the inside of her office, the sound of McInnis placidly describing his conversations with the Overseers, Nascimbeni lamenting the lunatic things his adopted nephew had been spouting in the caves, even his own voice talking about the frantic race through A&R with Melissa Bradbury. He remembered yesterday, starting at around... well, around 6:27. And he remembered the hours before that too, remembered going through the motions, sending Wirth's ghost to its more than certain doom, and being astonished that all they had to do was precisely what they'd done, and the disaster silently stopped itself.

And before that, an average Tuesday in the salt mines.

And before that, a Monday.

And before that, Sunday night. At the movies, in Grand Bend.

With his girlfriend.

"We had a fight yesterday," his girlfriend whispered.

He nodded. "That I do remember."

"So yesterday still happened, just not..."

"...everything else," he finished for her.

"Yeah."

"Do you know what the fight was about?"

"No." She frowned.

"Do you want to know?"

She cocked her head to one side, her long, long curly hair falling down almost to the floor. "No," she said finally, "I don't think I do."

He stood up. "Me either."

"There's a sick feeling in my stomach, Harry."

"Yeah?"

"Yeah. I feel like someone took one of my organs out."

He bit his lip. "I've got something similar."

She took a step towards him. "I want a hug."

He opened his arms. "I've got a spare."

[[=]]
@@ @@
[[image http://scp-wiki.wdfiles.com/local--files/the-b-b-decommission/Asterisk43.png]]
@@ @@
[[/=]]

He lay there beside her, listening to the sound of her breathing, taking in the desert scent that followed her everywhere she went. It was clean, and warm, and exotic in a way that nothing else in his life came close to. He realized that he loved her, and it took him by surprise. He hadn't meant to fall in love.

He'd never meant to fall in love again.

Not after what had happened with Melissa Bradbury.

After she'd woken up.

+ ##669933|2003##
++ 11 October
[[/=]]

----

"You're doing great."

"No," she wheezed. "I'm not."

"Baby steps," he encouraged her. She was hauling her body along the rails, withered muscles straining with the effort. Forsythe was standing not a metre away, watching them both nervously, ready to jump in if it looked like the trembling, too-pale woman was about to collapse.

"Fucking," Melissa grunted. "Baby steps." Hands slipping forward by inches, atrophied legs staggering like she'd just been gutshot. "I'm not--"

"I didn't mean--"

"Don't--"

"I'm sorry--"

"INTERRUPT ME!" she hollered, and nearly fell. He reached out to grab her, and she kicked him away.

"I'm sorry!" He raised his hands, holding them away from her.

"Don't be sorry! Just..." She wheezed. "Back off!"

"Don't overdo it," he said. He knew he shouldn't be saying anything, but he couldn't stop himself. She was back. She was //back.// He had her back in his life again. "It's early days."

"That's what. Fucking. //LeClair// keeps saying." She was panting with the effort required to move even a few short steps.

"She's the expert," he agreed.

"So why are //you// here?"

"I'm trying to help..."

"I don't need." Her arms were shaking on the rails.

"If you want me to come back later--"

"Don't," she hissed, and she sank to the floor. She stayed that way a while, cross-legged. He didn't know what to do. What to say.

She solved it for him by speaking again. "I'm sorry."

He sat down beside her. "It's okay."

She shook her head, pony tails obscuring her eyes. "It's not."

He put an arm around her shoulder. "It is."

She shook her head silently, then slipped out of his grasp.

"We'll try again later. Get the chair."

++ 15 October

----

"Get out!" she cried as he walked into the room.

He darted for the panel on the wall. "Dr. Bradbury's fallen."

"On the way, sir," a nurse's voice responded.

"Get out!" she repeated, and he moved to help her.

She was lying on the floor beside her bed. Her shirt and pants were wet. There was water all over the floor.

It wasn't water--

"GET OUT!" she screamed, tears streaming down her face. "GET OUT! GET OUT! GET OUUUUUUUUUUT!"

++ 19 October
[[/=]]

----

"You know I can't tell you," Ngo sighed as she packed her files away in the cabinet.

"Actually, you can." He leaned on the wall, and crossed his arms.

"How do you figure?"

"She and I are on the 5056 file together. We //opened// that file together. Now that she's off active duty, it's all on me to finish it up. If that monster did something to her, something lasting, I need to know about it. To update the file."

The psychologist shook her head. "I don't buy it."

"I wasn't really asking you to buy it. I'm telling you I require this information for an active SCP file."

"I think you should leave this alone for now." She walked back to her desk.

He followed her. "Why? You think I should ask her directly? Because--"

"No." She sat down. "If you haven't, it's probably because you can tell there //is// something more going on, something very bad, and you know not to bring it up and upset her. But it's still her business. I judge it nonessential for the 5056 file."

"I can overturn that judgement," he reminded her. "Allan would back me up."

Ngo shrugged. "Probably. Are you sure you want to go that way?"

++ 21 October
[[/=]]

----

They were both lying on her hospital bed, Melissa under the covers, Harry above them. The hospital staff were beginning to talk. He wondered what he was going to say to Udo. He wondered if any of them had already said something to her.

Melissa was staring at the wall-mounted television screen. It was playing some truly abominable romantic comedy film. He wasn't paying it any attention. The moment he saw her own attention wander, and she glanced over at him, he said: "You know I'm always here if you need to talk."

She nodded, expression neutral. "Yeah, you never give me a moment's peace. My bed smells like you."

"Is that so bad?"

She rolled her eyes. "Don't you have work to do?"

"Why, you want to help?"

She looked away. "No."

"It might be good for you."

She exhaled sharply, and grabbed the remote to turn off the television. "Why are you so sure you know better than I do what's good for me?"

His heart sank, not for the first time. "I don't want to argue."

"Well, I do." She made direct eye contact for the first time that day. "Let's make this about what I want. Wait on me hand and foot. Ask if I need my ass wiped. Spoon feed me, because I'm a pudgy-cheeked helpless little //baby.//"

"You do have pudgy cheeks." He briefly considered pinching one, just to see what would happen.

She was visibly unamused. "Take this fucking seriously. Let there be one thing in the world you don't think is a big joke."

"I've never thought of you as a joke."

"Stop it!" She inhaled long and hard, filled her cheeks, and stared at the ceiling. She was probably already popping her ears with the pressure. "Just stop it."

He tried to say something encouraging, but what came out instead was somehow "I don't know what I'm doing wrong."

"Forget to show up some day! Get pissed off at me! Start a fight!" she told the gypsum tiles and fluorescent lights.

"I don't want to."

She reached over and shoved at his face, pointing it up at the ceiling as well. "Stop looking at me like I'm some emaciated kid in a UNICEF commercial you can save with a fucking donation. I don't need your charity, and I don't... I don't deserve it."

"What does that mean?" he asked softly.

She closed her eyes. "I'm not who you think I am. You don't know me."

"I know you better than I've ever known anyone."

"Then you've never known anyone."

He took a sharp breath of his own.

"You don't know me. You're wasting your time. You're wasting //my// time."

"But this is where I want to be."

"I don't want you here."

She let the words hang in the air, long enough that he could feel they had no weight. They floated up into the air recyclers, lighter even than the gossamer hair she'd tucked into a tight braid behind her neck.

"If I tell you I want you to leave," she asked, "will you?"

"Yes. But--"

"Leave."

"//But,// you have to promise me, //promise me// you're not just doing it to hurt yourself. If you're really sick of me and don't want me around, I'll... you can say that, and I'll go, but--"

"STOP BEING SO FUCKING NOBLE ABOUT IT!" she shouted, looking at him again. "Go back to your god-damn girlfriend. What do you even want from me? There's no prize at the end of this. I'm not going to be able to walk properly for months, and that's not all I've got going on."

"I know."

"You don't need a friend who's lying around collecting bedsores, and I don't need to see that sad fucking face..." She paused, and her arched brows tilted inward. "What do you mean?"

He blinked. "What?"

"What do you mean, you know? What do you know?"

He couldn't lie to her. "I know there's something else."

Her eyes narrowed to slits. "Like what?"

"I //don't// know." He threw up his hands. "I've been hoping you'd tell me. I tried asking Nhung, but--"

Her cheeks were finally taking on some colour. "You did what?"

"I was worried, alright?" His heart began to race. "Something is obviously eating--"

"What did she tell you?"

"She didn't tell me anything!" He could feel the situation spinning out of control, and began to talk faster. "I shouldn't have asked. I was just afraid--"

"I don't want you around," she said flatly.

"It was a mistake. I know!" He kept his hands up, as though he could physically defend himself from her entirely earned indignation. "But I did it because... Jesus Christ, Mel, you know what I--"

"I want you to leave," she hissed, "and don't come back. Don't //ever// come back."

"Melissa--"

"I don't need you. I don't want you. I never did."

"I lo--"

She slapped him.

"You're a selfish, lazy opportunist, and you're trying to take advantage of me. Go prey on some other weak thing that still can't see you for what you are."

Never before in his life had a thing like this happened. She had spoken to him, and the only way he could think to respond was by getting as far away from her as physically possible. He stood up from the chair and hurried around the foot of the bed, badly banging his knee and not even feeling it, then rushed into the ward corridor and let the lines painted on the walls lead him out. He held it together down the long connecting passage and through the northern dorms, feeling like he had descended to crush depth and desperately needing fresh air to reinflate his lungs. The elevator came when he called it, and there was nobody waiting to ride down when it hit topside. He brushed past the security checkpoint, out the secret door, out of the disused barracks block and onto the tarmac. He walked around the back, towards the trees, but he didn't make it that far.

He fell to his knees beside a Dumpster, and started puking and crying while the birds wheeled and called overhead and the sickly sweet scent of baking garbage filled his nostrils. He wasn't waiting for the right time. He wasn't waiting for her to wake up. He wasn't waiting for her to get better. For the first time in seven years, he had nothing at all to wait for.

He felt like someone had died.

He wasn't sure if it was him or her.

He'd never distinguished a difference before.
